IMAGE-THUMBNAIL CATCOM 2921 S1566-7367(11)00412-2 10.1016/j.catcom.2011.10.022 Fig. 1 XRD diffraction patterns for NTB5, NTB10, NTB10-5, NTB5-5 and SGTB3 catalysts. The code A in the Figure means anatase phase, H2Ti3O7 means titanic acid phase and H2Ti5O11·H2O means hydrated titanic acid. Fig. 2 N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms for SGTB3, NTB5, NTB5-5, NTB10 and NTB10-5 catalysts. Fig. 3 Pore size distribution for SGTB3, NTB5, NTB5-5, NTB10 and NTB10-5 catalysts obtained from the desorption branch of the corresponding isotherm using the BJH equation. Fig. 4 HRTEM for SGTB3 catalyst nanocrystals annealed at 300°C with Fast Fourier Transformed showing anatase plane (101) located at 25.41° theta. Fig. 5 HRTEM for NTB10 catalyst. Fresh catalyst titania nanotubes (A), titania nanotubes annealed 300°C (B), titania nanoribbons annealed 500°C (C). Fig. 6 HRTEM for NTB5 catalyst. Fresh catalyst titania nanoribbons (A), titania nanoribbons annealed 300°C (B), titania nanoribbons annealed 500°C (C). Fig. 7 FTIR spectra of titania nanotubes in the absortion band of hydroxyl species (A) NTB10 and (B) NTB5 catalysts. Fig. 8 FTIR spectra of titania nanotubes in the absortion band of hydroxyl species (C) SGTB3, (D) NTB10-5 and (E) NTB5-5 catalysts. Fig. 9 UV–vis spectra of TiO2 nanocrystals and nanotubes catalysts. Fig. 10 XPS spectra for NTB5, NTB10 catalysts hydrothermally treated and SGTB3 catalyst synthesized by the sol–gel method. Fig. 11 XPS spectra for NTB10, NTB5 and SGTB3 catalysts. (A) O1s and (B) Ti 2P cores. Fig. 12 CO conversion as a function of the catalyst temperature. 500ppm of CO and 2% by vol of oxygen. The total flow gas was 400cm3/min and 100mg of catalyst was used. Table 1 Pore structures of the catalysts treated with NaOH at different concentrations. Catalysts SBET (m2/g) Dp (Å) Vp (cm3/g) NaOH (N) Phase Crystallite size (nm) Eg (eV) SGTB3 186 36 0.168 – Anatase 7 3.10 NTB10 290 82 0.578 10 H2Ti3O7 15 2.85 NTB5 220 142 0.427 5 H2Ti5O11.H2O 17 2.99 NTB10-5 82 46 0.094 – Anatase 19 3.15 NTB5-5 55 188 0.257 – Anatase 25 3.00 Short Communication Active TiO2 nanotubes for CO oxidation at low temperature R. Camposeco a S. Castillo a b ⁎ I. Mejia a V. Mugica c R. Carrera b A. Montoya a Moran-Pineda M. Morán-Pineda a J. Navarrete a Gomez R. Gómez d a Molecular Engineering Program, Mexican Institute of Petroleum, México, D.F., Mexico b Department of Alloy Engineering, ESIQIE-IPN, México D.F., Mexico c Department of Chemical, UAM-A, México, D.F., Mexico d Department of Chemical, UAM-I, México, D.F., Mexico ⁎ Corresponding author at: Molecular Engineering Program, Mexican Institute of Petroleum, México, D.F., Mexico Tel.: +52 55 9175 6738; fax: +52 55 9175 9699. In this study we report the formation of nanocrystals and nanotubes of TiO2 synthesized by the sol–gel method and hydrothermal treatment respectively. The obtained TiO2 nanostructures were characterized by XRD, BET, TEM, UV–vis, XPS and FTIR; and evaluated in the CO oxidation. As for the nanotube-based samples, two catalysts were prepared (NTB5 and NTB10) through the hydrothermal treatment of nanosized titania in NaOH (5 and 10N) at 160°C, followed by HCl rinsing until pH 1 was reached. From both catalysts, NTB10 showed the highest surface area (290m2/g), nanocrystals (15nm) and stable phase (H2Ti3O7) with a high CO oxidation capacity. We found that the band gap for NTB10 catalyst was of 2.85eV, the lowest value respect to that of NTB5 and SGTB3 catalyst, based material (SGTB) showed both the lowest textural properties and catalytic performance. Graphical abstract Nanotubes, nanoribbons and nanocrystals could become to be the main technology to remove CO at low temperature, even at room temperature, from the polluted urban air. Highlights ► Nanocrystals and nanotubes of titania by sol–gel were synthesized. ► Alkali concentration affect the textural and morphological properties of TiO2. ► Titania nanotubes catalyze, by themselves, the CO oxidation at low temperature. ► Titania nanotubes based catalyst are a powerful tool for facing the air pollution. Keywords Titania Nanocrystals Nanotubes Sol–gel method Hydrothermal treatment CO oxidation 1 Introduction Nowadays, TiO2 has been widely employed because of the promising opportunities for its application in environmental catalysis; likewise, TiO2 has been generally used as catalyst due to its optical and electronic properties, low cost, high photocatalytic activity, in solar cells for the production of hydrogen and electric energy, in ceramics, as anode for lithium-ion batteries, and non-toxicity [1,2]. High surface area and optimum pore size are required for this kind of catalysts to get high catalytic activity either by itself or with active metals. Currently, the exploration of novel approaches for TiO2 nanostructured by controlling both the particle size on a nanometric scale and morphology is quite interesting, since the performance of titania in its various applications depends on its crystalline phase state, size and morphology [3]. The design of catalytic systems to remove carbon monoxide (CO) from the atmosphere is the great interest for the environmental protection due to their potential in the air quality control. In this line, it has been reported that TiO2 nanocrystals and nanotubes with active metals present high activity in the reaction of CO [4]. However, the catalytic activity of titania is influenced strongly by the chemical and structural properties of the catalyst. In this line, it has been suggested [5,6] that the catalytic properties of TiO2 for CO oxidation are related to the particle size and morphology of the support. Furthermore, catalytic performance of titania catalysts depends on the preparation method [7,8]. In particular, hydrothermal treatment of TiO2 synthesized by sol–gel method modifies the catalytic properties of the catalyst and improves their activity to remove CO compared to that conventional preparation, such as traditional impregnation. Hydrothermally synthesized titania nanotubes were first reported by Kasuga et al. [9], likewise, these materials have been extensively studied over the last decade owing to their layered tubular morphology and high surface area, related with properties such as high catalytic activity and selectivity [10,11]. Nanosized materials synthesized from TiO2 have been studied for other important applications, for instance, as solar cells/batteries, electrode materials and medicine due to their chemical properties and physical behavior [12–14]. In fact, downsizing materials in the 1–100nm range modifies their mechanical, optical, magnetic and electronic properties as well as chemical reactivity [15]. In general, TiO2 with the anatase phase has been transformed into nanotubes, nanorods and nanowires through the hydrothermal method [16]. The transformation of anatase commercial from Deggussa P-25, hombikat anatase phase and commercial Sigma-Aldrich into nanotubes by alkaline hydrothermal method are widely used [17,18]. However, the formation of nanotubes strongly depends on the materials used in the synthesis. In this line, the use of alkoxides as a starting material has not been widely employed to produce nanotubes. In this work, the synthesis of nanosized TiO2 was achieved by the sol–gel method with special textural and morphological properties. The TiO2 nanocrystals and nanotubes were characterized by XRD, BET, FTIR, TEM and XPS. We found a surface area from 290 and 220m2/g for the catalysts NTB10 and NTB5. These catalysts showed a band gap respectively of 2.85 and 2.99eV and structure phase titanic acid (H2Ti3O7 and H2Ti5O11.H2O). The acid phase of these catalysts promotes probably the oxidation of carbon monoxide at low temperature (80°C). We also survey and discuss the main factors that affect the CO oxidation on TiO2 nanostructures under temperature reaction programmed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of nanosized TiO2 The nanosized TiO2 was prepared by the sol–gel method (SGTB) as follows: 43.9ml of titanium butoxide (Aldrich 97%) was dissolved in 300ml of butanol (Baker 99.4%). The solution was set under constant stirring, and then HNO3 was added to adjust the reaction medium at pH 1. The hydrolysis was accomplished by adding bidistilled water. The solution was maintained under stirring and reflux until the gel was formed. Afterwards, the gel was dried at 80°C for 12h, and then annealed in air at 300°C for 4h. 2.2 Preparation of TiO2 nanotubes Titania nanotubes were prepared by hydrothermal treatment. 3.5g of anatase (crystal size 7nm) synthesized by sol–gel method TiO2 into 250ml 10 and 5N aqueous NaOH solution were mixed in a closed cylindrical Teflon-lined autoclave Parr reactor (with capacity of 500ml) at 160°C for 48h while rotating the whole autoclave intensively at 200rpm. Afterwards, the solution was filtered with HCl until reaching pH 1; and then, it was washed with abundant deionized water to reach pH 7. Finally; the material was dried under vacuum at 80°C for 12h. The material was annealed in air at 300°C for 4h. The catalysts pretreated hydrothermally were labeled as NTB5 and NTB10. 2.3 Catalytic reaction Samples of 100mg of catalyst were tested in a tubular quartz reactor mounted in a temperature-programmed electronic furnace (Chromalox 2104). A porous quartz frit disk was placed in the middle of the tube to support the catalyst. Before the activity measurements, the model catalyst was heated at 120°C for 1h under flow of 100cm3/min of N2. Three flow controllers were used to measure flow rates of O2 +N2, CO+N2 and N2. Certified standard N2 and gas mixtures were acquired and purchased from Infra and Praxair (México). The feed stream composition was 500ppm of CO and 2v/v% of O2. N2 was the gas balance and the total flow was 400cm3/min. The analysis of reactants and products was made on line by means of a Fourier Transform-Infrared (FTIR) spectrophotometer (Bruker IFS 66 v/S) equipped with a 10m path-length gas-cell. Spectra were acquired at a 4cm−1 resolution by averaging 44 scans. We also used a gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC 12A) on-line equipped with a molecular Sieve 5A column. During catalytic runs the temperature of the reactor was raised from 25 to 400°C at 4°C/min. 2.4 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples packed in a glass holder were recorded at room temperature with Cu Kα radiation in a Bruker Advance D-8 diffractometer having theta–theta configuration and a graphite secondary-beam monochromator. The data were collected for scattering angles (2θ) ranging from 4° to 80° with a step of 0.02° for 2s per point. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) analyses of the samples were performed in a JEOL 2200FS microscope operating at 200kV and equipped with a Schottky-type field emission gun and an ultrahigh resolution pole piece (Cs=0.5mm, point-to-point resolution, 0.190nm). The samples were ground, suspended in isopropanol at room temperature and dispersed by ultrasonic agitation. Then, an aliquot of the solution was dropped on a 3mm diameter lacey carbon copper grid. Textural properties were determined in an ASAP-2000 analyzer from Micromeritics. The specific surface area was calculated from the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation from N2 physisorption at 77K. The pore size distribution was obtained by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method from the desorption branch. Infrared (IR) spectra were obtained using a Nicolet-710 Fourier transform-infrared. FTIR spectra were obtained with vacuum chamber Spectra Tech DRIFTs equipment. These spectra were registered after accumulation of 50 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1 with a flow of nitrogen at 10cm3/min. The flow of nitrogen was maintained during the measurements (25 to 500°C). A thermo scientific, evolution 600, UV–vis spectrometer was used to directly record the diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) between 200 and 800nm using the reflectance spectra as reference at room temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with a Thermo VG Scientific Escalab 250 spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical electron analyzer and an Al Kα radiation source (1486.6eV) power at 20kV and 30mA, respectively. The binding energy (BE) was determined by using carbon C (1s) line as reference with a binding energy in 284.6eV. The powder samples were pressed into a disk and placed on a sample holder in a vacuum chamber. The spectrometer was operated at 23.5eV pass energy and the base pressure in the analyzing chamber was maintained on the order of 3×10−8 mbar. Peak fitting was done using XPSPEAK 41 with Shirley background. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD The NTB5 and NTB10 samples synthesized from the reaction between the sol–gel TiO2 annealed at 300°C and highly concentrated NaOH (5 and 10N, respectively) were analyzed by the XRD technique. The results are shown in Fig. 1 . We found that the anatase is the principal phase used as starting material, SGTB3 catalyst. SGTB3 was also analyzed by means of Scherrer equation and we found that the crystal size of the SGTB3 catalyst was around 7nm. Titanium oxide nanotubes can be formed between 100 to 180°C with either crystalline anatase or rutile phase [19]. The concentration of the NaOH solution is also a critical parameter during the formation of nanotubes [20]. The XRD pattern of NTB10 is also shown in Fig. 1. This catalyst, NTB10, presents a monoclinic titanic acid, H2Ti3O7, which showed peaks at 2θ values of 9.7, 24, 28, 32.2, 48.4 and 50.02°, in agreement with previous work [21]. This kind of nanotubes can be stable when they are annealed below to 450°C; above this temperature, the structure collapses [22]. It is evident that when the temperature increases at 500°C the structure is clearly deteriorated, as a consequence the peak located at 9.7° disappeared, but appeared again reflections of the (101), (004), (105), (211), and (204) planes of the tetragonal structure of the anatase phase. In fact, at 500°C the formation of any crystals of anatase increases from 7 to about 19nm as the case for NTB10-5, as we will see in Fig. 6(C), alike behavior showed the catalyst NTB5-5, but with a higher crystallinity and larger crystal size of 25nm compared to NTB10-5 catalyst. With respect to NTB5 catalyst, it shows several peaks that correspond to a monoclinic phase of H2Ti5O11·H2O whose are shown by the appearance of the peaks at 2θ values of 11 and 24.5°, that correspond to (200) and (110) reflections of H2Ti5O11.H2O respectively, indicating complete transformation into a structure of layered hydrogen titanates (A2TinO2n+ 1.H2O), where A represents Na and/or H [23]. H2Ti5O11.H2O may be related with nanoribbons; this sort of structure can be indexed with monoclinic phase, but it does not exhibit high area, which can be due to the concentration of NaOH [20]. 3.2 Textural properties N2 adsorption–desorption shows isotherms which provide detailed information about the surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution of the NTB and SGTB catalysts annealed to 300 and 500°C, see Fig. 2 . NTB5 and NTB10 catalysts are mesoporous materials and show type IV isotherms and H3 hysteresis loop (IUPAC classification) [24,25]. The isotherms of the SGTB3 and NTB10-5 catalysts (mesoporous material) are also type IV with an H2 hysteresis loop, see Fig. 2. With regard to NTB5-5 catalyst we found that specific area decreases but the hysteresis loop H3 do not change. NTB5 and NTB10 catalyst exhibit specific areas respectively of 220 and 290m2/g. The specific area of the NTB5 and NTB10 is about 1.2 and 1.5 times higher than that of the SGTBs catalysts. The main feature that shows the nanotubes are high superficial area and mesoporosity. These properties are ideal for applications in the catalysis field. Table 1 and Fig. 3 present the pore size distributions of the NTB10 and NTB5 catalysts that were calcined at 300°C. Fig. 3 reveals a bimodal distribution of pore diameters for NTB10 and NTB5 catalysts, whose maximum are located at 30–50Å and 300–500Å, respectively. For this kind of distribution, it has been reported that the smaller pore of 30–50Å corresponds to the inside diameters of the sample NTB10 and the larger pores of 300–500 are the space between the nanotubes in the nanotubes-bundles [26,27]. Besides, with the assistance of the technique HRTEM we can observed details of materials mesoporous [28] as, for instance, TiO2 nanotubes presented in this work, see Fig. 5(A). With regard to the samples SGTB3 and NTB10-5 the pore distribution reveals a unimodal distribution reached a maximum at 20–40Å. Table 1 summarizes the physical properties of the NTB and SGTB catalysts. 3.3 HRTEM morphology Fig. 4 displays HRTEM of the anatase phase SGTB3 powder that was used to prepare NTB10 and NTB5. Our result indicates that the starting material, SGTB3, comprises particles around of 7nm. The prepared titania nanotubes, NTB10, see Fig. 5(A), has uniform morphology and open-end tubular structure with external and internal diameters of 10 and 3.5nm respectively. After annealing at 300°C, see Fig. 5(B), we can observed that the interlayer spacing between the walls of nanotubes are still conserved. These fringes have a space of 0.4nm. The nanotubular morphology was maintained according to the HRTEM analysis. From the comparison between Figs. 4 and 5(A) we can conclude that the titania nanocrystals were transformed into titania nanotubes via hydrothermal treatment at 160°C for 48h. The figure clearly show that the tubular structures are well defined crystalline tubes with multiple shells of 1 to 3 layers, and the space between the shell spacing is about 0.75nm, see Fig. 5(A). However, there are many defects present in the shell layers of the tubes. In Fig. 6(A), that correspond to NTB5 catalyst, it can be observed that it shows a better random order than that of the NTB10 catalyst; besides, this sample, NTB10, does not present internal diameters, as we can see in Fig. 6(B). It can be noted that the interlayer spacing between the walls of the nanotubes disappeared; only present a layered surface. The NTB5 catalyst shows nanoribbon morphology; see Fig. 6(B). The fringes parallel to the ribbon correspond to an interplanar distance of about 0.7nm. The Fast Fourier Transformed (FFT) pattern shows characteristics classified as (2 0 0), see Fig. 6(B) [29]. Figs. 5(C) and 6(C)) show that those samples annealed at 500°C, NTB10-5 and NTB5-5 that the structure of nanotubes and nanoribbons are collapsed and present a larger crystal size of the anatase phase of 19 and 25nm, respectively with respect to SGTB3, which is of 7nm. 3.4 FTIR DRIFT spectra of the OH region of the catalysts used in this work is presented in Figs. 7 and 8 . All spectrums of the NTB and SGTB catalysts show the presence of a broad absorption where two different bands, centered at 3400 and 3100cm−1, are overlapped. These bands are related to the coupled OH stretching modes from multilayer molecular arrangements of H-bonded water. The bands observed at 3656–3667cm−1 correspond to the highly groups basic OH in terminal position due to stretching modes of TiOH [30]. A further increase of the temperature up to 300°C produce that water molecules are removed, leading to a decrease in the intensity of the bands at 3400 and 3120cm−1. We observed the same effect for that band located around 1640cm−1. This band is assigned to the bending molecule water. A narrow band at 3670cm−1 increase along with temperature, which is ascribed to the stretching mode of bridging hydroxyls, which proton is expected to be weakly bonded [31,32]. At even higher temperatures (500°C), an additional band at 3730cm−1 appears which is assigned to the vibrational mode of terminal OH groups on Ti4+ centers. This band is clearly detected in the NTB10 and NTB5 catalysts see Fig. 7. For SGTB3 and NTB10-5 catalysts we found remarkable differences. For instance, SGTB3 catalyst presents more stretching modes TiOH with respect to NTB10-5 spectra, this may be due to the collapsed of the nanotubes structure and new onset appear of the domains of anatase phase with a crystals size greatest than SGTB3. In the NTB10-5 catalyst spectra a narrow band at 3651cm−1 is observed, it band is related to the stretching mode of free OH from a second layer of water [33]. In the NTB10 catalyst spectra, small bands at 2908cm−1 are also detected, and can be attributed to the presence of residual organic compounds on the catalyst surface. The Dehydroxylation grade in the titania nanotubes occur during the treatment between 400 and 500°C. It may be due to the breaking nanotubular TiOH bonds producing TiOTi bonds. This phenomenon was also confirmed using UV–vis technique, we observed that visible absorption band of the NTB10 catalyst annealed at 300°C increased (red shift 435nm). When NTB10-5 catalyst is treated at 500°C the visible absorption band decreased (blue shift 393nm) due to the collapse of the nanotubular structure with a size crystal greater than NTB10, see Table 1. 3.5 UV–vis The diffuse adsorption spectra for NTB5, NTB10, SGTB3 and NTB10-5 and NTB5-5 catalysts are shown in Fig. 9(A). The optical absorption edge energy is defined as the minimum energy required to excite an electron from de highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO at the top of the valence band) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO at the bottom conduction band) [34]. The diffuse reflectance measurements in the UV region enabled us to determine the band gap energy of the semiconductors by extrapolation to the energy x-axis of the linear interval in a (αhv)2 vs. hv plot [35]. Firstly, to establish the type of band-to-band transition in these catalysts, the absorption data were fitted to equations direct band-gap transitions. There are two types of electronic transitions, direct and indirect [36]. Fig. 9(B) shows the (α E photon)2 vs. E photon for a direct transition, where α is the absorption coefficient and E photon is the photon energy, E photon= (1239/λ) eV, where λ is the wavelength in nanometers. The value of E photon extrapolated to α =0 gives an absorption energy, which corresponds to the band-gap (Eg). The absorption edge energy has also been shown to depend on crystallite size for small nanocrystals (less than 100nm) for which bonding energy remains constant [37]. TiO2 band gap appears in the 380–459nm region, and the band gap of the anatase phase is 3.2eV [38]. In our case, for the five catalysts, the values fluctuate between 2.85 and 3.15eV, the band-gap obtained for the NTB5 (2.99eV) and NTB10 (2.85eV) catalysts is lower than anatase phase (3.2eV) and that reported to commercial TiO2 Degussa P-25 (3.0eV) [38]. Therefore, we suggest that it is possible that the sol–gel method allows the modification of the band-gap, as previously reported [39]. The band-gap energy for the NTB5 (2.99eV) and NTB10 (2.85eV) is smaller than that of the SGTB (3.1eV) catalysts. The reduction of the band-gap could be due to the effect produced by the annealed temperature of the SGTB catalyst. Besides, it is important to note that NTB5 and NTB10 catalysts have a structure of nanotubes and SGTB catalyst is only formed by nanocrystals. In this line, we also suggest that nanotubes present lower band-gap energy respect to the nanocrystals structures. More investigation is in progress in this line to elucidate this statement. 3.6 XPS XPS analysis was carried out in order to obtain the electronic state of TiO2-supported. The survey of NTB5, NTB10 and SGTB3 catalysts, see Fig. 10 , present signals originating from O 1s, Ti 2p1/2, Ti 2p3/2 and N 1s that are easily identified at binding energies around 531, 464, 458 and 397eV, respectively. The features observed at 1224, 1108, 1075 and 979eV correspond to the Auger peaks of C, N, Ti and O. It is also possible to observe in Fig. 10 that signals of metals, as Mg and Ca, are not found, due to those compounds are not present in the support because they were eliminated during the washing process. It is relevant to say that we used deionized water to prepare the support in order to avoid those impurities. With respect to the shapes of the XPS Ti 2p, we found two peaks close to 464 and 458eV, which most likely correspond to Ti4+ 2p1/2 and 2p3/2. This clearly revealed that the titanium elements were in the oxidation state IV, corresponding to Ti4+ (TiO2) [40], see Fig. 11(B). Our analysis of O1s spectra for the NTB5, NTB10 and SGTB3 catalysts using deconvolution show the relation among the different oxygen species where the first peak is related to predominantly oxygen in the crystal lattice TiO (at 529.5eV). The second peak correlates with the surface hydroxyl OH− (at 530.3eV) and the third peak is related to physical adsorbed water (at 531.6eV), see Fig. 11(A). The peak that present NTB10 catalyst for the O 1s spectrum is relatively high especially in the amount of oxygen from the lattice of titania nanotubes compared with NTB5 and SGTB3 catalyst, see Fig. 11(A). The highest content of OH-groups was observed for NTB10 catalysts, followed by NTB5 and SGTB3 catalysts see Fig. 11(A). This result was confirmed during the FTIR experiments. The different crystalline structure, crystal size and surface area of the anatase and rutile components may also affect the adsorption of water and the formation of hydroxyl groups [41]. In our case, NTB10 catalyst that present nanotubular structure and a specific area of 290m2/g showed the highest amount of OH-groups respect to that NTB5-5, that present nanocrystals structure and has an surface area of 55m2/g. 3.7 Catalytic activity Fig. 12 presents the CO conversion over NTB5, NTB10, SGTB3 NTB10-5 and NTB5-5 catalysts as a function of temperature. We found that NTB5 and NTB10 catalysts start the CO oxidation at 80°C. The further increase in temperature promotes the CO conversion up to 100% at 300°C. On the other hand, SGTB3 catalyst showed less catalytic activity. It catalyst only reached around 63% of CO conversion at 400°C. NTB10-5 catalyst, which was previously annealed at 500°C, showed alike behavior reaching around 58% of CO conversion at 400°C. NTB5-5 starts the CO oxidation at 250°C. It catalysts only reached 30% of CO conversion at 400°C. During the catalytic test we do not observed formation of H2. The main product was CO2. However, at 330°C was detected a peak of H2 (close to 400ppm) over NTB10 catalyst. H2 was produced probably via water gas-shift reaction between CO and H2O. We can conclude that oxidation of CO is the main reaction activated by the catalysts. H2 formation is not showed in Fig. 12. The transformation of titania nanocrystals to titania nanotubes seems to be related with CO oxidation. Nanotubes catalysts, NTB5 and NTB10, present a higher area and a large amount of OH-groups respect to the nanocrystals. In this line, it has been suggested that water can easily dissociate on TiO2 surface over O2 vacancies to form OH Hydroxyl groups. Those groups promote the catalytic reaction of carbon monoxide [45,46]. In our case, we do not feed water in the reaction gasses. There are discrepancies in the open literature about the effect of water on CO oxidation. It has been reported that addition of water vapor to the CO oxidation feed has a positive effect on Au/TiO2, Au/Al2O3 and Au/Mg(OH)2, but has no effect on Au/Fe(OH)3 [42]. However, Date and Haruta [43] showed that, depending on the partial pressure of H2O in the system, its effect could be to suppress or enhance the activity. It is clear that H2O, or OH-groups in our case, plays an important role in generating active catalysts, the exact nature of this role is not yet understood. It is possible that OH-groups have a direct effect on the catalytic active site, but more investigation is needed. However, the generation of these OH-groups stronger depends of the catalyst morphology, TiO2 nanotubes in our case H2Ti3O7, H2Ti5O11.H2O. Other factor involved in the reactivity is the particle size and crystal plane of the catalyst [44]. The reaction of CO with O2 over supported catalysts is an important reaction for both industrial and automotive pollution control. The synthesis of materials as nanotubes, nanoribbon and nanocrystals with high catalytic activity for the low temperature oxidation of CO, even at room temperature, can become to be the best technology to remove CO from urban polluted air. 4 Conclusions The handling of the sol–gel variables permitted the synthesis of titania nanocrystals with improved textural and morphological properties such as high specific area, high purity and stable anatase phase with respect to the starting materials. In a second stage, TiO2 obtained by the sol–gel method with NaOH (5 and 10N) at 160°C was transformed into nanoribbons and nanotubes, which showed higher specific area with respect to nanocrystals. From the analysis of the catalytic activities of the TiO2 nanoribbons and nanotubes (NTB5 and NTB10), it was found that these ones showed a performance that was better than that of SGTB (nanocrystals) catalysts. Particularly, the change from titania nanocrystals to titania nanotubes (nanoribbons and nanotubes) shows important differences. The surface area increased, pore volume and pore diameter also increased and the material were remained as mesoporous material. The transformation from anatase phase TiO6 into scrolling H2Ti3O7 and H2Ti5O11·H2O was performed. We also observed that the band gap decrease and the OH-groups increase. According to the aforesaid, the titania-nanotube-based catalysts could be used as a powerful tool for facing the air pollution. coredata.dc:description: In this study we report the formation of nanocrystals and nanotubes of TiO2 synthesized by the sol–gel method and hydrothermal treatment respectively. The obtained TiO2 nanostructures were characterized by XRD, BET, TEM, UV–vis, XPS and FTIR; and evaluated in the CO oxidation. As for the nanotube-based samples, two catalysts were prepared (NTB5 and NTB10) through the hydrothermal treatment of nanosized titania in NaOH (5 and 10N) at 160°C, followed by HCl rinsing until pH 1 was reached. From both catalysts, NTB10 showed the highest surface area (290m2/g), nanocrystals (15nm) and stable phase (H2Ti3O7) with a high CO oxidation capacity. We found that the band gap for NTB10 catalyst was of 2.85eV, the lowest value respect to that of NTB5 and SGTB3 catalyst, based material (SGTB) showed both the lowest textural properties and catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Active TiO2 nanotubes for CO oxidation at low temperature
